statement:
[**Theorem -**]{} A universal net
$ (x_{\alpha})_{\alpha \in \mathcal{A}}$ in a compact space $ X$ is
convergent.

[**Proof :**]{} Suppose by contradiction that
$(x_{\alpha})_{\alpha \in \mathcal{A}}$ was not convergent. Then for
every $x \in X$ we would find neighborhoods $U_x$ such that
$$\forall_{\alpha \in \mathcal{A}}\;\;\; \exists_{\alpha \leq \alpha_0} \;\;\; x_{\alpha_0} \notin U_x$$

The collection of all this neighborhoods cover $X$, and as $X$ is
compact, a finite number $U_{x_1}, U_{x_2}, \dots, U_{x_n}$ also cover
$X$.

The net $(x_{\alpha})_{\alpha \in \mathcal{A}}$ is not eventually in
$U_{x_k}$ so it must be eventually in $X-U_{x_k}$ (because it is a net).
Therefore we can find $\alpha_k \in \mathcal{A}$ such that
$$\forall_{\alpha_k \leq \alpha} \;\;\; x_{\alpha} \in X-U_{x_k}$$

Because we have a finite number
$\alpha_1, \alpha_2 \dots, \alpha_n \in \mathcal{A}$ we can find
$\gamma \in \mathcal{A}$ such that $\alpha_k \leq \gamma$ for each
$1 \leq k \leq n$.

Then $x_{\gamma} \in X-U_{x_k}$ for all $k$, i.e.
$x_{\gamma} \notin U_{x_k}$ for all $k$. But
$U_{x_1}, U_{x_2}, \dots, U_{x_n}$ cover $X$ and thus we have a
contradiction. $\square$
names: universal nets in compact spaces are convergent
